description:
Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Education has decided to close all government schools in the country from March 13th until April 20 due to the risk of coronavirus spreading in the country. Catholic and Buddhist Dhamma schools will also be closed till April 20th.  The closure was then extended to May 11 and then extended further indefinitely. The closure of these schools has been cancelled from June 29 onward, and is set to reopen in four stages. 
 UPDATE: The original policy of public school closure that was set to first last until April 20 and then up to May 11 and then extended until further notice has been cancelled from June 29 onward. Schools are now set to reopen from June 29 in four stages.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Sri Lanka announced that arrangements are made to vaccinate the general public against the Covid 19 virus, using the Oxford-Astra Zeneca vaccine starting February 15 2021. description: SSri Lanka is vaccinating people over 60 years of age and those with chronic illnesses in the Western Province who have not received the first dose of the Covid vaccine over three days. The National Operation Center for the Prevention of Covid 19 Outbreak is collecting information on people in the Western Province over 60 years of age who have not received their first dose on August 10, 2021. The vaccinations will occur from August 11-14.

description: In Sri Lanka, all non-essential travel is not permitted from 11.00pm to 4.00am daily. Only 1 person per household is permitted to leave the house on a given day based on the last digit of the National Identity Card (NIC) number. NICs with even numbers can leave home on even numbered days, and those with odd numbers can leave home on odd numbered days. Only exceptions are for purposes of work and for obtaining health services. These restrictions are in effect from 12.05.2021 until 31.05.2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On January 26th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that all passengers from flights originated from China need to be screened for temperature. If a passenger with elevated temperature is detected, he/she should be given a surgical mask to wear and taken to the health office.      All suspected 2019-nCoV patients need to be screened by airport health office (APHO) medical officers. Consent for examination and further assessment should be obtained from the traveler or parent of guardian. If consent is not given, the traveler/s will be managed under the authority given by the Quarantine and Prevention of Diseases Ordinance.      If the traveler has a contact history and fever/signs and symptoms, the traveler should be transferred to IDH/ designated hospitals.Director or a designed officer from these hospitals should immediately contact the Chief Epidemiologist and the D Quarantine and should immediately provide relevant patient information for required surveillance, prevention and further actions.      Passengers Locator Form should be filled for those travelers with suspected nCoV seated in the same row and two rows in front and behind the index suspected case. The details should be communicated to the Epidemiology Unit, which will carry out the community level contact tracing and house quarantine of asymptomatic contacts with the help of Regional Epidemiologist and MOOH.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
On 22 May 2021, the Ministry of Health in Sri Lanka has laid down specific guidelines for private hospitals that conduct COVID-19 RT PCR and Rapid Antigen testing. 
1. The tests should be carried out only when it is indicated as per the recommendations of the Consultant or the Medical Officer in charge of the triage counter.
2. After taking the samples, the patients should be advised to isolate inside the institution/home until the report is issued.
3. If a patient is found to be a COVID-19 positive, is it the responsibility of the hospital to inform the Epidemiology Unit of the Ministry of Health, the Medical Officer of Health in the respective areas and the patients.
4. The positive patients have to be arranged to be accommodated in Authorized COVID-19 Treatment Centres as per the recommendation of the responsible physician.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
On 23 May 2021, the Ministry of Health in Sri Lanka has laid down specific guidelines for private hospitals that conduct COVID-19 RT PCR and Rapid Antigen testing.
1. The tests should be carried out only when it is indicated as per the recommendations of the Consultant or the Medical Officer in charge of the triage counter.
2. After taking the samples, the patients should be advised to isolate inside the institution/home until the report is issued.
3. If a patient is found to be a COVID-19 positive, is it the responsibility of the hospital to inform the Epidemiology Unit of the Ministry of Health, the Medical Officer of Health in the respective areas and the patients.
4. The positive patients have to be arranged to be accommodated in Authorized COVID-19 Treatment Centres as per the recommendation of the responsible physician.
5. No walk-in or drive through PCR or Rapid antigen testing permitted

description: On January 26th, Sri Lanka announced testing criteria for Novel Coronavirus (nCoV): 1) Patients with severe acute respiratory infection (fever, cough, and requiring admission to hospital), AND with no other aetiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND at least one of the following: a. history of travel to or residence in the city of Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, orb. Patient is a heath care worker who has been working in an environment  where severe acute respiratory infections of unknown aetiology are being cared for. 2) Patients with any acute respiratory illness AND at least one of the following: a. close contact with a confirmed or probable case of 2019-nCoV in the 14 days prior to illness onset, or b. visiting or working in a live animal market in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or c. Worked or attended a health care facility in the 14 days prior to onset of symptoms where patients with hospital-associated 2019-nCov infections have been reported.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 19th March, 2020, Sri Lanka's Government Information Department announced that curfew has been imposed in the Wattala and Ja-Ela Police Divisions from 10.00 pm until further notice.

On March 18th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that police curfew has been imposed in the Puttalam and Chilaw police divisions and Kochchikade in the Negombo Police Division from 4.30pm until further notice with the aim or controlling the spread of the Coronavirus (Covid-19).

The police curfew has been imposed to prevent the flouting of rules and regulations imposed under the quarantine and disease prevention Ordinance.

Those engaging in placing deposits for election and handing over nominations and those reporting for work will be permitted to travel.

Further, all essential services and public transport through these areas would also not be hampered despite the curfew being imposed. UPDATE: The curfew has now been imposed on the whole nation from 6pm March 20 to 6am March 23, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Commencing on 21 April 2020, a total of nine Sri Lankan Airlines special flights were used to destinations in India (Punjab, Mumbai, Coimbatore, Bangalore, New Delhi and Kolkata) Pakistan (Karachi and Lahore), Nepal (Kathmandu) and Bangladesh (Dhaka), to repatriate the Sri Lankan students who had expressed their desire to return to Sri Lanka in the wake of the COVID 19 Pandemic. The operation to bring home 1065 Sri Lankan students based in the South Asian region, over 10 days, reached a successful conclusion on 30 April 2020.

description: In Sri Lanka, it has been observed that certain electronic media broadcast illustrations harm the privacy of individuals, such as the manner they are taken into quarantine or hospitalization and their homes or their surroundings. In some cases, patients and associates are perceived as anti-social by some of the media. Some people may not even seek treatment or quarantine because of the risk of socializing such scenes that harm their privacy. The heads of all media institutions have been requested to not shoot or telecast scenes that could harm the privacy and social dignity of those suspected of being infected with Covid-19 or their associates from now on (11 October 2020).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: The media has been requested to not shoot or telecast scenes that could harm the privacy and social dignity of those suspected of being infected with Covid-19 or their associates from now on
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 10 June 2020, Sri Lanka announced an acronym DReAM that is required to be followed.
D- Social Distance, no gatherings, mainly stay at home
Re- Respiratory Etiquette
A- aseptic practices (hand wash, hand sanitizing)
M- proper use of mask
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Sri Lankan health authorities made a press release on 7 August 2021 to strongly advise the public to strictly adhere to the instructions below.
- Get vaccinated against the coronavirus. Most of the infected people worldwide survived due to vaccination.
- Do not leave home unless it is essential.
- Do not participate in weddings, funerals and other similar events where people gather in large numbers.
- Remember to wear a face mask when visiting public places.
- Do not stay in closed spaces such as rooms, halls, elevators, vehicles etc. when crowded.
- Wash your hands using soap from time to time.
- Stay away from others keeping a distance of more than two meters.
- If you have a chronic illness, do not leave home except for work.
- Do not entrust safety of yours and your family with others and take that responsibility into your hands.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 11 May 2021, Sri Lanka is implementing quarantine measures for all travellers arriving from overseas,  Sri Lanka staff members serving in Diplomatic Missions/UN Organizations overseas, foreign national staff members of the diplomatic missions/UN organizations and other relevant officials. Children below two years are exempted from Day One and exit COVID-19 PCR testing. All travellers of twelve years and above should undergo Day 11 to 14 PCR testing. All travellers should be released from the Quarantine Hotel/Quarantine Centre/Safe and Secure Certified Level 1 Hotel after completion of fourteen days of quarantine with negative COVID-19 test results done on Day One (On arrival) and Day 11 to 14. Quarantine period of above mentioned travellers will be extended, if they are identified as immediate close contacts of a COVID-19 positive person. This quarantine measure is effective until 31st May 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On 8 May, 2020, Sri Lanka is facilitating limited activities of a salon considering this service as a public need during the prevailing COVID-19 outbreak. Only the following procedures shall be performed in the salon: cutting/trimming of hair, dyeing of hair, manicure and pedicure and waxing of arms and legs.
Any owner/manager who intends to open his\her salon should make a request to the Medical Officer of Health in his area.
Workforce arrangements should be made to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

description:
On 2 November 2020, Sri Lanka released guidelines for restriction of activities in Non Curfew imposed areas affecting businesses. 

For cars and trishaws, the maximum number of passengers is limited to two. For other types of vehicles, it is limited to 50% of the seating capacity.

Utility services are allowed to provide all essential services but with minimum of staff.

Export oriented industries (including garment, agriculture, etc) are allowed to function within a bio secure bubble, under close supervision of area MOH.

Agriculture/livestock are allowed to operate normally with strong adherence to DReAM.

Street vendors and construction sites are allowed with strict adherence to guidelines.

Mobile vendors are restricted to essential supplies.

Boarding houses can remain at full capacity but no new persons should be given accommodation.

A maximum of 25% of the total capacity can be allowed at a given time in pubs and bars.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Bars") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 2 November 2020, Sri Lanka released guidelines for restriction of activities in Non Curfew imposed areas affecting businesses. A maximum of 50% of the total number of customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time in supermarkets, shopping malls, financial institutions, clothing/textile shops, groceries, open markets/fairs, economic centres, bakery shops, barber and beauty salons, laundries, tailors and dressmakers, communication/photography shops, day cares, preschools, gymnasiums, indoor sports halls, restaurants, betting centres, hotels, rest houses and guest houses (on the basis of 1.5m2 of available walking space can be considered adequate for 1 person). Gatherings and entertainment in the mall premises are strictly not allowed.

description:
In Sri Lanka, the following regulations are effective from May 1, 2021.

Supermarkets, shoppers malls, financial institutions, textile shops and retails shops should be operated within 25% of the total customer capacity.

Pubs and bars, betting centers and spa centers are closed.

The occupancy in hotels, rest houses and guest houses should be 50% of the total capacity and should not function after 10pm

Open markets, fairs and bakeries should operate at 25% of the total customer capacity.

Tuition classes will be closed until further notice.

description:
From 12 May to 31 May 2021, Sri Lanka is applying restrictions and regulations to the following businesses.
Bakery, Barber and Beauty Salons, Furniture, Electrical, Hardware stores, Laundry, Tailors and dressmakers, Communication/photocopy shops - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside.
Street/mobile vendors - Allowed with strict adherence to guidelines and DReAM
Filling stations - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Constructions sites - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Health Sector - Must function with required number of staff to maintain service requirement, adhering to the instructions given
Boarding houses - Can remain at full capacity adhering to the instructions given but no new persons should be given accommodation
Restaurant (dining in) - A maximum of 25% of the total seating capacity can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Group dining should be restricted to a maximum of 8 persons.
Restaurant (take away/delivery) - Normal operations with strong adherence to DReAM
Pubs and bars - Closed
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
From 12 May to 31 May 2021, Sri Lanka is applying restrictions and regulations on the following businesses.
Private taxi services - Ensure the maximum number of passengers is limited to two for cars and trishaws. For other types of vehicles, it is limited to transport seated passengers only.
Utility services (electricity, water, telecommunication, petrol stations, LP gas stations, motor garages/tyre services and postal/courier services - Provide all essential services with minimum staff. Others to work from home where feasible
Private sector offices - With minimum number of staff required. Others to work from home where feasible.
Export Oriented Industries (Garments, agriculture etc.) - Function within a bio secure bubble (i.e. ensure secure accommodation and transport for workers) under close supervision of area MOH.
Supermarkets - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. 1.5m2 of available walking  space can be considered adequate for 1 person. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside.

Conferences/Seminars/Brand launches - Not permitted until further notice
Shopping Malls - For shops: A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. 1.5m2 of available walking space can be considered as adequate for 1 person inside the individual shops. Agriculture based - Normal operations with strong adherence to DReAM
Open market/fairs, economic centres - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given.

description:
In Sri Lanka, the following regulations are effective from May 1, 2021.

Supermarkets, shoppers malls, financial institutions, textile shops and retails shops should be operated within 25% of the total customer capacity.

Pubs and bars, betting centers and spa centers are closed.

The occupancy in hotels, rest houses and guest houses should be 50% of the total capacity and should not function after 10pm

Open markets, fairs and bakeries should operate at 25% of the total customer capacity.

Tuition classes will be closed until further notice.

 UPDATE: The rules and regulations regarding businesses were updated on 12 May 2021.

description:
From 12 May to 31 May 2021, Sri Lanka is applying restrictions and regulations to the following businesses.
Bakery, Barber and Beauty Salons, Furniture, Electrical, Hardware stores, Laundry, Tailors and dressmakers, Communication/photocopy shops - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside.
Street/mobile vendors - Allowed with strict adherence to guidelines and DReAM
Filling stations - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Constructions sites - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Health Sector - Must function with required number of staff to maintain service requirement, adhering to the instructions given
Boarding houses - Can remain at full capacity adhering to the instructions given but no new persons should be given accommodation
Restaurant (dining in) - A maximum of 25% of the total seating capacity can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Group dining should be restricted to a maximum of 8 persons.
Restaurant (take away/delivery) - Normal operations with strong adherence to DReAM
Pubs and bars - Closed UPDATE: Lockdown started on 21 May 2021 and only essential goods and service providers will be allowed to remain open during the period travel restrictions are relaxed.

description:
From 12 May to 31 May 2021, Sri Lanka is applying restrictions and regulations on the following businesses.
Private taxi services - Ensure the maximum number of passengers is limited to two for cars and trishaws. For other types of vehicles, it is limited to transport seated passengers only.
Utility services (electricity, water, telecommunication, petrol stations, LP gas stations, motor garages/tyre services and postal/courier services - Provide all essential services with minimum staff. Others to work from home where feasible
Private sector offices - With minimum number of staff required. Others to work from home where feasible.
Export Oriented Industries (Garments, agriculture etc.) - Function within a bio secure bubble (i.e. ensure secure accommodation and transport for workers) under close supervision of area MOH.
Supermarkets - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. 1.5m2 of available walking  space can be considered adequate for 1 person. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside. UPDATE: Lockdown started on 21 May 2021 and only essential goods and service providers will be allowed to remain open during the period travel restrictions are relaxed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On 22 June 2021, Sri Lanka announced the following business regulations in districts except for those in the Western province.

Meetings: Essential meetings only with maximum of 10 participants
Conferences/Seminars/Brand launches: Hybrid events (virtual and physical) with maximum 25 onsite participants
Street vendors: Registered vendors allowed under strict health regulations
Shopping complex: Loitering/gathering/activities/entertainment not allowed in common spaces
Ready-made garment and textile shops: A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given.

Tailors and dress makers, communication/photocopy shops, and other retail/service related agencies/shops: Maximum of 3 customers allowed to be inside at a given time.
Furniture/hardware shops/laundry svc: Normal functions. Ensure that there is no crowding.
Pubs and bars: Closed
Hotels, rest houses and guest houses: Closed UPDATE: From August 15, 2021, restaurants are permitted to cater not more than 50% of their capacity at a time.

description:
On 18 April, 2020, the President of Sri Lanka announced that only 1/3rd of the total workforce of the state organizations located within the Colombo district should report to work. 50% of the staff of the state organizations in other districts should report to work. All the employees of the state sector who are not required to report for work in office should work from their homes. The responsibility to decide who should come to office and who should work from home lies with head of the each organization.

Measures recommended by the health authorities to control the spread of the virus should strictly be adhered to during office hours. The head of the organization is responsible for the provisions of facilities required to follow the recommended health guidelines.

description: The Department of Pensions in Sri Lanka announced on 10 June, 2020 that a system is to be implemented to ensure maximum security for the pensioners, preventing large crowds from gathering in the department at the same time. Pensioners should arrive at the department by reserving a specific date and time online. At present, the department has developed a new system and pensioners who wish to visit the department can make their appointments through the departmental website. Departmental services are available at Divisional Secretariats. The Department of pensions advises its main beneficiaries, the senior citizens of the country, to stay at home and obtain the services of the department via 1970 hotline or at the Divisional Secretariat level whenever possible.

description:
In Sri Lanka, restrictions will be put in place once universities are re-opened from 15 June 2020.
- Seating arrangements and the number to be accommodated in an examination hall as well as at practical sessions should be in accordance with health guidelines
- During this period, the universities are advised to encourage students as much as possible to enter the university premises to sit for the examinations straight from home
- When arranging hostel accommodation, a room should be accommodated only one student until further notice
- Students should leave university premises (including the Library) at least by 7 pm everyday until further notice
- No get-togethers or any king of gatherings inside or outside the premises of universities be permitted until further notice
- No recreational and sports activities should be permitted until further notice

description: On 2 November 2020, Sri Lanka released guidelines for restriction of activities in Non Curfew imposed areas affecting the public sector. Public transport are only allowed to transport passengers up to 75% seating capacity of the bus/train. A maximum of 50% of the total number people that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed in courts at a given time. Children’s parks are closed. Beaches are open but no gatherings are allowed. Walkways are open only to walks by self and no crowding allowed. UPDATE: The restriction and regulation of government services were updated on 12 May 2021.

description: Sri Lanka established on March 25th a special mechanism to deliver essential food items to homes. Medicine will be delivered to the homes of regular patients who have registered at hospitals with the support of Divisional Secretaries, Public Health Officers and the security forces. Authorities was requested to implement a programme to supply domestic gas at consumer’s doorstep responding to the telephone orders.The objective of the entire project is to prevent the public from gathering at market places so that the health sector’s efforts to combat the coronavirus could be a success.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Announced on 7 April 2020, Sri Lanka is introducing a mechanism to streamline the issuing of curfew permits to avoid people gathering in large numbers to get curfew permits.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 50 or more employees located in Colombo District of Western province will be issued by the Police Headquarters.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 50 or more employees  will be issued by the Office of the Deputy Inspector General of Police in Charge of the Province that they are located.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 10-50 employees located in each Police Division will be issued by the respective Offices of the Superintendents of Police in Charge of the Divisions.

Curfew permits for industries/institutions/companies with less than 10 employees and individuals on extreme humanitarian reasons are issued by police stations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18 April, 2020, the President of Sri Lanka announced that all forms of functions, pilgrimages and pleasure tours, carnivals, processions and meetings are banned until further notice. Since the congregation of people is a hindrance to the preventive measures to control the spread of the virus, the Government also requests to suspend all religious festivals.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From Friday, June 12, 2020, assemblies at religious places in Sri Lanka are subject to the follow restrictions.
- The maximum number that any religious place of worship can gather while maintaining social distance (including buildings and open spaces of the religious place) is limited to 50 persons
- For religious places where there is no room for at least 50 persons to gather maintaining the social distance, only half the number of people can gather at the premises can stay at one time. UPDATE: Gathering at religious places of worship was banned from 1 May 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Sri Lanka announced on 22 June 2021 that marriage registrations are allowed with 10 participants including bride and groom. Funerals (except COVID-19 Deaths) should be held within 24 hours of release of the body from the hospital/inquirer in to sudden deaths with maximum 15 participants at a given time. UPDATE: It was announced on August 6, 2021 that the maximum number of persons that can attend a wedding in a reception hall with the capacity of more than 500 seats is limited to 150. If the number of seats in the reception hall is less than 500, the maximum number of attendees is limited to 100.
Only 25 people are allowed to attend each funeral.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 8 May, 2020, Sri Lanka is facilitating limited activities of a salon considering this service as a public need during the prevailing COVID-19 outbreak. Only the following procedures shall be performed in the salon: cutting/trimming of hair, dyeing of hair, manicure and pedicure and waxing of arms and legs.
Any owner/manager who intends to open his\her salon should make a request to the Medical Officer of Health in his area.
Workforce arrangements should be made to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Sri Lanka's director general of health services, stated on March 24, that social distancing of one meter apart should be maintained at all times. He reiterated that social distancing should continue even after the curfew that was imposed is lifted. On May 25, it was announced that Police could arrest anyone not complying with this social distancing policy from May 26 onward. UPDATE: The original social distancing policy of at least one meter apart was first advised on March 24 and not enforced as mandatory. On May 25 it was announced that the police could arrest anyone not complying with this policy from May 26 onward.

description:
From June 29, 2020, tuition classes in Sri Lanka will be subject  to the following restrictions.
- Maintaining the social distance depending on space available in the class, the maximum number permitted to attend a tuition class is limited to 100 students
- In case of tuition classes that do no have classrooms/room facilities for 100 students, only half the number of students are allowed
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 12 May to 31 May 2021, Sri Lanka is applying restrictions and regulations to the following businesses.
Bakery, Barber and Beauty Salons, Furniture, Electrical, Hardware stores, Laundry, Tailors and dressmakers, Communication/photocopy shops - A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside.
Street/mobile vendors - Allowed with strict adherence to guidelines and DReAM
Filling stations - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Constructions sites - Allowed with adherence to DReAM
Health Sector - Must function with required number of staff to maintain service requirement, adhering to the instructions given
Boarding houses - Can remain at full capacity adhering to the instructions given but no new persons should be given accommodation
Restaurant (dining in) - A maximum of 25% of the total seating capacity can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Group dining should be restricted to a maximum of 8 persons.
Restaurant (take away/delivery) - Normal operations with strong adherence to DReAM
Pubs and bars - Closed
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Boarding houses - Can remain at full capacity adhering to the instructions given but no new persons should be given accommodation
Restaurant (dining in) - A maximum of 25% of the total seating capacity can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given. Group dining should be restricted to a maximum of 8 persons.
Restaurant (take away/delivery) - Normal operations with strong adherence to DReAM
Pubs and bars - Closed UPDATE: Lockdown started on 21 May 2021 and only essential goods and service providers will be allowed to remain open during the period travel restrictions are relaxed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants

description:
On 22 June 2021, Sri Lanka announced the following business regulations in districts except for those in the Western province.

Meetings: Essential meetings only with maximum of 10 participants
Conferences/Seminars/Brand launches: Hybrid events (virtual and physical) with maximum 25 onsite participants
Street vendors: Registered vendors allowed under strict health regulations
Shopping complex: Loitering/gathering/activities/entertainment not allowed in common spaces
Ready-made garment and textile shops: A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time adhering to the instructions given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses

description:
In Sri Lanka, the following business regulations is in effect from 22 June 2021.

Private taxi services: 2 passengers only
Utility services and other essential services: Function with minimum staff required. Others to work from home where feasible.
Industries (Garments & other industries): Permitted to function strictly within a modified bio secure bubble
Financial institutions (banks, finance companies, pawning centers etc.): Open. The total number of customers should not exceed 10 at a given time. Function with minimum required staff. Others to work from home where feasible.
Agriculture/Plantation: Open
Open market/fairs: Open. Under strict restrictions by local authorities
Economic centers: Open for wholesale business under strict health restrictions
Mobile vendors: Registered vendors allowed to deliver essential commodities under strict health regulations
Groceries: Open. Maximum 3 customers at a time are allowed adhering to the instructions. Maximum number allowed should be displayed outside.
Supermarkets: A maximum of 25% of the total number customers that could be accommodated in the space available can be allowed at a given time.
Barber and beauty salons: Maximum of 1 customers can be accommodated at a time in the space available for restricted functions (cutting/trimming/dyeing of hair, manicure, pedicure and waxing of arms/legs). By appointment only.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In Sri Lanka, the following business regulations is in effect from 22 June 2021.

Restaurant (dining in): Closed
Restaurant (delivery/take away): Closed. Online orders allowed under strict health regulations
Motor garages/tyre services/service centres: Normal functions. Ensure that there is no crowding.
Bakeries and pastry shops: Delivery and take away allowed. Maximum 3 customers at a time are allowed adhering to the instructions.
Tailors and dress makers, communication/photocopy shops, and other retail/service related agencies/shops: Maximum of 3 customers allowed to be inside at a given time.
Furniture/hardware shops/laundry svc: Normal functions. Ensure that there is no crowding.
Pubs and bars: Closed
Hotels, rest houses and guest houses: Closed
